Intro.text:
See
pulmonary embolism in pregnancy
for pregnancy specific information.
[1]

Clinical_Spectrum_of_Venous_thromboembol.text:
Deep venous thrombosis
(uncomplicated)
Phlegmasia alba dolens
Phlegmasia cerulea dolens
Venous gangrene
Pulmonary embolism
Pulmonary embolism in pregnancy
Isolated distal deep venous thrombosis
Only 40% of ambulatory ED patients with
PE
have concomitant
DVT
[2]
[3]

Massive:_High-risk.text:
Hemodynamically unstable with symptoms of shock
ACCP 2016 CHEST Guidelines: Sustained hypotension ONLY criteria (systolic BP <90 for at least 15min or requiring inotropic support)
Previous definitions (e.g. AHA 2011) include cardiac arrest/pulselessness or persistent profound bradycardia (HR <40 with signs of shock)

Submassive:_Intermediate-risk.text:
Right ventricular dysfunction (RVD) and/or myocardial necrosis in the absence of persistent hypotension or shock (SBP >90)
[5]
RV dysfunction
RV dilation or dysfunction on TTE
"D Sign" on bedside echo (LV takes on a "D" shape due to RV dilation)
RV dysfunction on CT defined as RV/LV ratio >0.9
[6]
Elevation of BNP (>90)
ECG findings of right heart strain (see diagnosis below)
Myocardial necrosis: Troponin I >0.4

Non-Massive:_Low-risk.text: No hemodynamic compromise and no RV strain

Sub-Segmental.text: Limited to the subsegmental pulmonary arteries

Epidemiology.text:
The best estimates indicate that 350,000 to 600,000 Americans each year suffer from DVT and PE
[7]
Survival
[8]
PE is the 3rd leading cause of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality
At least 100,000 deaths per year may be directly or indirectly related to DVT and PE
For almost one quarter of PE patients, the initial clinical presentation is sudden death
PE is an independent predictor of reduced survival for ≤3 months
One of the leading causes of out-of-hospital, non-trauma related sudden deaths
[9]

Symptoms.text:
According to the PIOPED II study, these are the most common presenting signs
[10]
Dyspnea
at rest or with exertion (73%)
Pleuritic
chest pain
(44%)
Cough
(37%)
Orthopnea (28%)
Calf or thigh pain and/or swelling (44%)
Wheezing
(21%)
Hemoptysis
(13%)

Signs.text:
Tachypnea
(54%)
Calf or thigh swelling, erythema, edema, tenderness, palpable cord (47%)
Tachycardia
(24%)
Rales (18%)
Decreased breath sounds (17%)
Accentuated pulmonic component of the second heart sound (15%)
JVD (14%)
Fever
(3%)

Assessing_Pretest_Probability.text:
Objective criteria (Geneva, Wells, etc.) is equal to gestalt in assessing pre-test probability
[11]
(ACEP Level B)
Initial Wells study and prospective validation
[12]
used a three tier system (low 0-1, intermediate 2-6, high >6) to establish pretest probability with a small sample size
The larger Christopher Study group used a larger sample size to derive the simplified dichotomized/two tier model below
[13]

Wells_Criteria.text:
Score 0-4 = PE Unlikely (12.1% incidence of PE)
Check
D-dimer
If D-dimer positive then obtain CTPA or V/Q scan
If D-dimer negative, no further workup needed (0.5% incidence of PE at 3 month follow up)
Score >4 = PE Likely (37.1% incidence of PE)
Obtain CT Pulmonary Angiography or V/Q Scan
New evidence suggests lower Wells Score with D-dimer <1000 ng/mL is effective at ruling out PE without imaging

tables.Clinical Features: Symptoms ofDVT(leg swelling and pain with palpation)
PEas likely as or more likely than an alternative diagnosis
Immobilization for >3 consecutive days or surgery in the previous 4 weeks
Malignancy (receiving treatment, treatment stopped within 6 mon, palliative care)

Low-Probability_Testing_in_the_ED.text:
PERC Rule
negative
, then no further workup
[11]
(ACEP Level B)
Avoid CT pulmonary angiography in low pretest probability patients that are either PERC rule negative or have a negative d-dimer (
ACEP choosing wisely
)
D-dimer NPV is 99.5%
[14]
PERC Rule
positive
, then
D-dimer
(see Moderate-Probability Testing below)
[11]
(ACEP Level B)
Can also consider using Wells score as above to determine further testing

Adjusted_D-Dimer_to_Higher_Threshold.text:
For certain patients a higher d-dimer can be used
[15]
Age Adjusted D-Dimer
YEARS Algorithm
PEGeD

Less_common_risk_factors.text:
HIV (protein wasting nephropathy)
Nephrotic Syndrome
SLE
with anti-cardiolipin Ab
Exogenous hormones (specifically estrogen)
homozygous
Factor V Leiden
Antithrombin III deficiency
Protein C deficiency
Protein S deficiency
Hyperhomocysteinemia
Sickle cell anemia
(S/S and S/beta thalassemia)
[16]

Evaluate_bleeding_risk_(HAS-BLED).text:
HAS-BLED score (developed to evaluate bleeding risk for anticoagulation in Afib) can also identify patients with acute VTE at high risk for bleeding complications within 6 months
[17]
When applied to VTE patients on vitamin K-antagonists, NOT DOACs (in first 6 months of treatment):
Score 0-2 = 1.3% incidence of major bleeds
Score 3+ = 9.6% incidence of major bleeds
Other bleeding risk models include the RIETE score (validated in patients taking VKA or rivaroxaban) and VTE-BLEED score (validated in patients taking warfarin and edoxaban).

tables.Management: Do not treat with anticoagulation while awaiting diagnostic test results
Treat with parenteral anticoagulation if the results of diagnostic tests are expected to be delayed ≥ 4 hours
Treat with parenteral anticoagulation while awaiting diagnostic test results

Definitive_Diagnostic_Imaging.text:
CTA Chest if GFR >60
V/Q scan if GFR <60
Will be nondiagnostic if patient has effusion, pneumonia, or other airspace disease
If imaging negative, perform additional diagnostic testing (e.g. lower extremity Doppler US, V/Q scan, and/or traditional pulmonary angiogram) prior to exclusion of VTE
[11]
(ACEP Level C)
A negative d-dimer in combination with a negative CTA theoretically provides a post-test probability of VTE less than 1%

Other_Possible_Diagnostic_Findings.text:
ECG
(abnormal in 70% of PE
[20]
and associated with an adverse prognosis
[21]
)
T-wave inversions (34%)
[22]
Anterior/septal leads (V1-V4) and inferior leads
[23]
T-wave flattening (30%)
Sinus Tachycardia (27%)
Right axis deviation (11%)
ST-segment changes in V1-V4 (9%)
S1Q3T3 RV strain pattern (4%)
New-onset atrial arrhythmias (e.g. atrial fibrillation)
New RBBB (complete or incomplete)
[24]
QR pattern in V1
CXR
(abnormal in 70%)
Atelectasis is most common (esp >24 hrs after onset of symptoms)
Pleural effusion
Hampton's Hump
Westermark's sign
[25]
Formal transthoracic echo
or
bedside cardiac ultrasound
Can help diagnosis in equivocal cases
May see signs of right heart strain (bowing of septum into LV; Aka D Sign)
Right ventricular strain is associated with statistically significant worse outcome
[26]
McConnell's sign- Right ventricular free wall akinesis that spares the apex
Lateral right ventricular wall diameter of <5mm is suggestive of acute pulmonary hypertension while >5mm is suggestive of chronic pulmonary hypertension
[27]
SPECT
Combination of non-contrast CT chest with V/Q scan
Avoidance of contrast for patients with renal injury
As sensitive as CTPA and more sensitive than planar V/Q scanning
[28]

[26]
McConnell's sign- Right ventricular free wall akinesis that spares the apex
Lateral right ventricular wall diameter of <5mm is suggestive of acute pulmonary hypertension while >5mm is suggestive of chronic pulmonary hypertension
[27]
SPECT
Combination of non-contrast CT chest with V/Q scan
Avoidance of contrast for patients with renal injury
As sensitive as CTPA and more sensitive than planar V/Q scanning
[28]

ECG
(abnormal in 70% of PE
[20]
and associated with an adverse prognosis
[21]
)
T-wave inversions (34%)
[22]
Anterior/septal leads (V1-V4) and inferior leads
[23]
T-wave flattening (30%)
Sinus Tachycardia (27%)
Right axis deviation (11%)
ST-segment changes in V1-V4 (9%)
S1Q3T3 RV strain pattern (4%)
New-onset atrial arrhythmias (e.g. atrial fibrillation)
New RBBB (complete or incomplete)
[24]
QR pattern in V1
CXR
(abnormal in 70%)
Atelectasis is most common (esp >24 hrs after onset of symptoms)
Pleural effusion
Hampton's Hump
Westermark's sign
[25]
Formal transthoracic echo
or
bedside cardiac ultrasound
Can help diagnosis in equivocal cases
May see signs of right heart strain (bowing of septum into LV; Aka D Sign)
Right ventricular strain is associated with statistically significant worse outcome
[26]
McConnell's sign- Right ventricular free wall akinesis that spares the apex
Lateral right ventricular wall diameter of <5mm is suggestive of acute pulmonary hypertension while >5mm is suggestive of chronic pulmonary hypertension
[27]
SPECT
Combination of non-contrast CT chest with V/Q scan
Avoidance of contrast for patients with renal injury
As sensitive as CTPA and more sensitive than planar V/Q scanning
[28]

Supportive_care.text:
Oxygen therapy (maintain SpO2 ≥90% unless otherwise indicated)
Hemodynamic support (e.g. IVF, pressors)
Consider gentle fluid challenge of 500ml normal saline bolus to improve cardiac index in select patients
[29]
Experimental studies suggest that aggressive volume expansion provides little benefit and may worsen RV function in those with acutely elevated RV afterload and acutely increased pulmonary HTN
[30]

Anticoagulation.text:
Always consider
bleeding risk
when determining risks/benefits of initiating anticoagulation
Treatment options include any of the following anticoagulations which are indicated for all patients with confirmed
PE
or high clinical suspicion (do not wait for imaging).
Duration
3-6 mo, if time limited risk factor (post-op, trauma, estrogen use)
6 mo to life, if idiopathic etiology or recurrent

tables.Name: Initial Dose
tables.LMWHSC: Enoxaparin1mg/kg SC q12hDalteparin200 IU/kg SC q24h, max 18,000 IU
tables.Unfractionated Heparin: 80 units/kg bolus; then 18 units/kg/hr continuous infusion
tables.Dabigatran: Parenteral anticoagulation for 5-10 days; then 150mg twice daily
tables.Rivaroxaban: 15mg twice daily for 3 weeks, then 20mg once daily
tables.Apixaban: 10mg twice daily for 1 week, then 5mg twice daily
tables.Coumadin: Cannot be administered alone for acute PE. Usual starting dose 5mg PO

tables.Name: Benefits
tables.LMWHSC: 1st line for most hemodynamically stable patientsPreferred in those with cancer, liver disease, coagulopathy, pregnancy
tables.Unfractionated Heparin: Short half-lifePreferred if rapid reversal is needed (e.g. considering thrombolytics or with bleeding risk/trauma)No need for renal dosing
tables.Dabigatran: Noninferior to warfarin in reducingDVTand PE[31]
tables.Rivaroxaban: Preferred if parenteral therapy to be avoidedAssociated with less bleeding, particularly in elderly patients and those with moderate renal impairment compared to standard treatments[32]
tables.Apixaban: Preferred if parenteral therapy to be avoided or if history of GI bleedingStudies show 16% reduction in VTE related death compared to standard therapy[33]
tables.Coumadin: Preferred in renal disease, history of poor compliance, or history of GI bleed

tables.Name: Contraindications
tables.LMWHSC: Severe renal impairment (CrCl <30 mL/min)Patients with morbid obesity or anasarca may have poor absorption
tables.Unfractionated Heparin: Use with caution in patients >60yoPrevious history of HIT
tables.Dabigatran: Avoid in CAD and in severe renal impairment
tables.Rivaroxaban: Avoid in hepatic disease (Child-Pugh Class B/C)
tables.Apixaban: Avoid in severe hepatic disease and renal impairment
tables.Coumadin: Temporary hypercoagulable state for approx 5 days

tables.Name: Comments
tables.LMWHSC: Dose adjustments may be necessary in obese patients
tables.Unfractionated Heparin: Check PTT after 6hr; adjust infusion to maintain PTT at 1.5-2.5x control
tables.Coumadin: INR target 2.5Consider many drug-drug interactions with CYP450 inhibitors or inducers

Subsegmental_PE.text:
Evaluate for proximal DVT in legs with ultrasound
If low risk for recurrent VTE: Clinical surveillance recommended over anticoagulation (
Level 2C
evidence)
[34]
If high risk for recurrent VTE: anticoagulation recommended over surveillance

Catheter-directed_Therapy_for_intermedia.text:
Includes catheter-directed thrombolysis and mechanical thrombus removal without thrombolysis
Still no large prospective cohort or randomized trial evaluating CDT, so limited evidence recommendations from ACCP 2016 are weak
Primary outcome measure in study of 59 patients was improved RV function at 24 hours, but not mortality
Given broad clinical spectrum of intermediate-risk PE, CDT can be considered in a subset of patients with following characteristics:
Intermediate-risk PE with more severe degree of RV dysfunction and positive biomarkers
Intermediate-risk PE with severe hypoxemia
High-risk (massive) PE with contraindications to systemic thrombolysis
Complications include major access site bleeding, significant arrhythmias, pulmonary artery dissection, tamponade, worsening hemodynamics

IVC_Filter.text:
Indications
anticoagulation contraindicated in patient with PE
failure to attain adequate anticoagulation during treatment

Still no large prospective cohort or randomized trial evaluating CDT, so limited evidence recommendations from ACCP 2016 are weak

Disposition.text:
Patients with significant clot burden generally require admission for anticoagulation
Consider discharge in low risk patients with peripheral PE
[36]
Risk stratify which patients can be discharged using HESTIA
[37]
, sPESI, or PESI scores
[38]
.

Prognosis.text:
The Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI)
[39]
PE patients with PESI class I or II seem safe to manage as outpatients.
